The last bit shows that there is no other way to calculate the area of a wedge like that than by dividing it to a triangle and a sector. This is IMHO one of the best showcases of sector being an unique area. It's the same thing about segment that it is a diffrence of a sector and a triangle.

So... I was feeling kind of hip so I started simplifying the 1/8 - cos(4x) /8 into terms with only x and I ended up with just sin^2(x) cos^2(x)..  Now that's pretty interesting right cause it's the same as the integrand plus a constant.  Anyone tried this?

Can someone help me? I don't have a good foundation for the details in math atm. I get the concepts really well, but I found something that doesn't make sense to me. When he is doing S (1-cos^2x)*sinx*cos^2x*dx = .... he adds the powers of cos^2x 's and makes it cos^4x. I tried pluging in numbers to see if this logic actually added up and it doesn't unless the base of the number with powers is 1. Is this because cos is considered 1 in some way? If I did 10^2 and 10^2... I get 10^4. lets say my formula is (1-10^2)*2*(10^2)*4=. well (1-100)*2*100*4 = -99*2*100*4 = -79200. But if I add those powers like so... (1-10^4)*2*4=-79,992. Doesn't add up. Anyone??? lol asking for a friend who knows what they are doing. I'm gonna go to school for this stuff but need to know what went wrong here. BTW as I said when the bases of the number with power being added are 1 it seems to work out.

funny, I have the opposite impression. Furthermore, I feel Jerison is way more exciting: with him I feel like I am  passing over the history of math and brilliant ideas... instead Miller is quite dry (imo of course).

@therfnoob7697  I should clarify that I do like Jerison as well. I find just prefer Miller's pedagogy. I find that Jerison has a tendency to explain things "mathemagically" (i.e. with very little explanation). Miller seems to go back to first principles frequently. But really, they are both very good. Different approaches each with their own strengths.

@therfnoob7697  yeah, I personally like the way Jerison teaches more than his sub. There are many professors who can teach methodically and rigorously , espeically in the field of science, but there aren't many professors who can summon up students' imgnative abilities and Jerison does that.
Both are great. But Jerison inculcates mathematical thinking rather than just procedure and that is unique.

At the end, the area is given in terms of the angle theta. I'm assuming this is in radians. Three questions:  1) What units is the solution in? Meters^2? 2) I assume you cannot simply change between radians and degrees, as that would cause the calculated area to be off by a factor of 180/pi? 3) If that is true, why not? What is special about radians that makes the solution specific to radians?

Well the median for the third exam (the one the students just took at the time of this lecture) was 82%, written on the board at the start. You can find the third exam on their online course (18.01) if you want to get an idea of the difficulty level.
Videos were not recorded during sessions 8, 17, 26, and 34 as these were in-class exams.
ThanQ very much

+Ken Burke    1. If it is an area, it has to be the square of a length.  2 and 3. You can change between radians and degrees. The solution can also be in degrees, since the units can cancel out to still give an area. The point is that, as you mentioned, there would be an extra factor in the equation.   We can actually have all our formulas in degrees. It's allowed. But radians is much easier to deal with, because you just tune it so that a circle is 2(pi) and you can break that down into however many pieces you want to without getting extra factors all over the place.
a and b has the dimensions of length. Now you got it?
units squared
